title: How do I close down a "S" corporation so that I do not have any legal obligations
question: We are an "S" corparation that will be ceasing operation. How do we go about legally desolving the company so that no one can file a legal claim against it.
answers:
Closing a business which is a form of California corporation would require formal 'wind up and dissolution' proceedings by taking the appropriate steps to avoid liability to creditors which may exist. Depending upon the assets/liabilities which may exist at the time of considering winding up - will be a primary factor as to which route to take in closing the business in order to avoid those potential ongoing legal obligations.
Richard M. Kelly

As my colleagues have noted, you need to pay the outstanding debts and taxes and attest to the CA Secretary of State that you've done so before you can formally dissolve the corporation.

If the business is still operating but has become too burdensome to maintain, maybe an S corporation wasn't the best choice and you may want to consider converting the S Corp into an easier to maintain LLC. Consult the business lawyer you hired to form the corporation for help.

The Secretary of State's website has a form for dissolution. You have to get Form DISS STK or DSF STK, depending upon the age of the Scorp. See weblink. You also need to get tax clearance as described on the form.
